They are in the [[Mojave National Preserve]], in the [[National Park Service]] system. ==Geography== The Granite Mountains are north of [[Interstate 40 in California|Interstate 40]] and historic [[U.S. Route 66 in California|Route 66]]. The [[Providence Mountains]] are adjacent to the northeast. The [[Bristol Mountains]] are directly to the west, the [[Old Woman Mountains]] are to the southeast, and [[Pisgah Crater]] and the [[Bullion Mountains]] are to the southwest. The Mountains lie east of the small community of [[Kelso, California|Kelso]], northeast of [[Ludlow, California|Ludlow]], and north of [[Amboy, California|Amboy]]. The range stretches from Granite Pass ({{coord|34|48|44|N|115|36|37|W|region:US}}) to Budweiser Wash ({{coord|34|49|16|N|115|45|32|W|region:US}}). ==Geology== Some of the more striking rock formations in the [[Mojave National Preserve]] lie in the Granite Mountains. These [[Granite|granitic]] rocks have eroded into unusual rounded shapes that include spires, perched boulders, and curved cliff faces. Granitic rocks represent the roots of ancient [[continental-margin]] volcanic systems. Most of the granitic rock in the Mojave Desert is late [[Mesozoic]] in age (80 to 180 million years old). The granites formed at depth within a volcanically active mountain range comparable in geologic setting to the [[Andes]] chain in [[South America]]. The granitoids formed by the slow cooling and solidification of molten [[magma]] bodies that developed above sinking slabs of [[oceanic crust]] overridden by the edge of the continent. At least 55 or 60 million years elapsed between the crystallization of the last [[Mesozoic]] magma bodies and deposition of the youngest-preserved overlying strata. Several [[spring (hydrosphere)|spring]]s exist in the Granite Mountains, though they may not flow year round. ==See also== *[[:Category:Mojave National Preserve|Category: Mojave National Preserve]] *[[:Category:Mountain ranges of the Mojave Desert|Category: Mountain ranges of the Mojave Desert]] == External links and sources == {{reflist}} * [http://vulcan.wr.usgs.gov/LivingWith/VolcanicPast/Places/volcanic_past_mojave.html America's Volcanic Past - Mojave National Preserve] (USGS PD source) {{-}} {{commons category|Granite Mountains (California)}} [[Category:Mojave National Preserve]] [[Category:Mountain ranges of the Mojave Desert]] [[Category:Protected areas of the Mojave Desert]] [[Category:Mountain ranges of San Bernardino County, California]] [[Category:Protected areas of San Bernardino County, California]]
